newsitem.title: USA: U.S. agency questions Boskin report on CPI.
newsitem.headline: U.S. agency questions Boskin report on CPI.

text.p: A government analysis has challenged some findings of a recent private-sector report on the U.S. Consumer Price Index, the head of a joint House-Senate economic committee said on Friday.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) identified several weaknesses in the so-called Boskin report, including the suggestion that the bureau inaccurately measured quality changes in CPI basket goods, Rep. Jim Saxton said.
Saxton, a Republican from New Jersey, requested the BLS analysis in his capacity as head of the House-Senate Joint Economic Committee.
The report, written by a panel headed by Stanford University Economist Michael Boskin, said the BLS overestimated U.S. consumer inflation by about 1 percentage point annually.
"Over the next 12 years, the Boskin Commission recommendations would amount to a trillion dollars in tax increases and benefit restraint," Saxton said in a statement.
"The immense impact of these changes affect too many people to permit hasty decisions on the basis of incomplete information," he added.
The BLS analysis said the Boskin report failed to take account of adjustments that are currently made to account for quality changes in CPI basket goods.
The analysis also said the formula for CPI revision suggested by the commission assumed a degree of substitution among goods and services that is not always appropriate.
"In addition, it is clearly wrong to assume that the CPI does nothing to take increased durability adjustments to auto prices made in the CPI since 1992," the analysis said.
